intro: Acaena coxi, commonly known as the New Zealand brambles, is a shrub native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its prickly stems and small, yellowish flowers. The plant produces small, round fruits that are typically reddish or black in color. Acaena coxi is adapted to a variety of soil types and thrives in temperate climates. It plays an important ecological role by providing food for native birds and insects.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena coxi is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the Canterbury region. This plant grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky areas. It is commonly associated with coastal and inland dunes. Acaena coxi is an important component of the local flora and is adapted to the specific environmental conditions of its native range.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena coxi was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there as part of the European flora during the colonial period. The plant has since become naturalized in various parts of the country. It is often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides. However, it is not considered a major invasive species in New Zealand.
